text:
Professor Dave again, let’s talk about the
Divergence Theorem.

Green’s Theorem 
gave us an additional method for calculating

a line integral around a closed curve. Now
we will introduce an additional method of

calculating the surface integral for a “closed”
surface S. By this we mean that we have some

solid region in space, and its boundary will
be our surface. Recall that the surface integral

for this will be expressed as the surface
integral over S, of F dot n dS, where F is

some vector field permeating space, and n
is the normal vector of the surface. The divergence

theorem, also called Gauss’s Theorem, states
that this surface integral is equal to the

triple integral over the solid region of the
divergence of F dV. Here, dV is our differential

volume, which in cartesian x, y, z coordinates
will simply be dx dy dz.

Let’s take a look at an example to see how
to apply this theorem. Consider the surface

of this triangular prism which occupies x
from 0 to 1 and y from 0 to 2. It has a flat

base in the xy plane, and the top surface
is given by the plane z = 1 – x. Now let’s

say there’s a vector field in this space
which is given by F = . If we

wanted to calculate the surface integral of
this field over the surface S without using

the theorem, we would have to split each of
the five flat surfaces of the prism into their

own surface integrals and calculate each individually.
Luckily, the Divergence Theorem reduces our

work to one triple integral over the region
of the prism. The divergence theorem states

that the surface integral will be equal to
the triple integral of the divergence of F

over the region, so first let’s find the
divergence of F. Recall that the divergence

of a vector field is del dot F where del equals
. So for this case the divergence

will be del dot F equals y + z + x. Now we
have the divergence, but before integration

we must get our bounds sorted out. We get
these from the region of our prism. One simple

way to express these bounds is integrating
z first, letting it run from 0 to 1 – x.

Now we don’t have any more complicated bounds,
so we can integrate y from 0 to 2 and x from

0 to 1. So our integral ends up being the
integral from 0 to 1, the integral from 0

to 2, the integral from 0 to 1 – x, of y
+ z + x dzdydx. Integrating z first, we get

yz + z^2/2 + xz, where z is evaluated from
0 to 1 – x. Factoring out a z and evaluating

we get (1 – x)[y + (1 – x)/2 + x] or simplifying
the x terms, (1 – x)(y + x/2 + 1/2). Next

we must integrate with respect to y, which
gives us (1 – x)(y^2/2 + xy/2 + y/2) where

y is evaluated from 0 to 2. Evaluating this
we get (1 – x)(2 + x + 1) or just (1 – x)(x

+ 3). Now if we multiply this out, we get
the integral of (x + 3 – x^2 – 3x) dx.

Simplifying gives us 3 – 2x – x^2. Integrating,
we get 3x – x^2 – x^3/3, where x runs

from 0 to 1. And finally, evaluating gives
us 3 – 1 – 1/3, simplifying to 5/3. This

is the value of our surface integral, which
we used the Divergence Theorem to calculate.

The divergence theorem is another useful tool
for calculations, and it has a variety of

applications. In fact, the theorem is used
in Gauss’s law to relate the flux of an

electric field, which would be the surface
integral part of the theorem, to the amount

of charge contained within the volume, which
would be the triple integral part of the theorem.

And with this, we’ve wrapped up another
section of mathematics, but before we go on
to more advanced topics, let’s check comprehension.
